sn15.13:4.1: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.
sn15.13:4.2: Then thirty mendicants from Pāvā went to the Buddha. All of them lived in the wilderness, ate only alms-food, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; yet they all still had fetters.
sn15.13:4.3: They bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
sn15.13:4.4: Then it occurred to the Buddha:
sn15.13:4.5: “These thirty mendicants from Pāvā live in the wilderness, eat only alms-food, wear rag robes, and own just three robes; yet they all still have fetters.
sn15.13:4.6: Why don’t I teach them the Dharma in such a way that their minds are freed from defilements without grasping while sitting in this very seat?”
sn15.13:4.7: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
sn15.13:5.2: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, hindered by ignorance and fettered by craving.
sn15.13:5.3: What do you think? Which is more: the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time, or the water in the four oceans?”
sn15.13:5.4: “As we understand the Buddha’s teaching, the flow of blood we’ve shed when our head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating is more than the water in the four oceans.”
sn15.13:6.1: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.
sn15.13:6.2: The flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.
sn15.13:6.3: For a long time you’ve been cows, and the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a cow is more than the water in the four oceans.
sn15.13:6.4: For a long time you’ve been buffalo …
sn15.13:6.10: For a long time you’ve been bandits, arrested for sacking villages,
sn15.13:6.12: or adultery. And the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a bandit is more than the water in the four oceans.
sn15.13:6.15: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed from all conditions.”
sn15.13:7.1: This is what the Buddha said.
sn15.13:7.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
sn15.13:7.3: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of the thirty mendicants from Pāvā were freed from defilements without grasping.
